(7/7)

* Avoid underlining, block capitals, & italics - Use bold instead
* Use left-justified with ragged right edge (don't full-justify)
* Avoid abbreviations & provide a glossary of jargon

The https://t.co/YMagvNLAK8 has a package to make linked jargon and glossary tables.

(6/7)

Highlighted recommendations from the Dyslexia-friendly Style Guide https://t.co/UMlvwkex35

* Use bullet points and numbering rather than continuous prose
* Use the active voice with concise, direct sentences
* Use boxes and borders (call-out blocks) for emphasis

* Avoid roman numerals
* Avoid text in figures
* Add alt text to figures

@seanpmackinnon In my experience with Registered Reports, there has always been an opportunity to fix errors in the registered analysis plan if all the authors and reviewers agree that they were overlooked errors.

@seanpmackinnon Errors in pre-reg can *definitely* be fixed posthoc. All you have to do is explain the error and allow the scientific community to judge whether it was a true error or a change due to motivated reasoning.

@hardsci So dichotomising analyses into prespecified and not isn‚Äôt helpful. Just say which aspects (if any) were prespecified, ideally with reference to code. Whether the prespecification increases (or decreases) your confidence in the finding is a specialist decision.

@hardsci Also the term ‚Äúpreregistered‚Äù has very little meaning without reference to exactly *what* was prespecified. Most analyses deviate slightly from the plan or failed to consider a decision that had to be made. And non-code plans have room for (mid)interpretation.

@MyKo101AB I am skipping xlim/xlab/labels/etc and just teaching scale_ functions, but needed to shorten the code for tweeting ;) But I've been convinced to never use limits (just filter data) and teach coord_cartesian as a separate concept to axis scale aesthetics.
@bmwiernik (So many book edits before class starts Friday!)

@bmwiernik I think I might teach student to *never* use limits in a plot, but to filter the data before plotting if required. I can't think of anything you could do with limits but not filtering (that wouldn't also require a pretty advanced understanding of plots).

@bmwiernik But once I'd identified the weird behaviour of binned axes with non-filtering limits, I just wanted to understand *why*. I've now got a better conceptual understanding of how limits work and how to *explain* the difference from coord_cartesian.

@bmwiernik I think I'm convinced enough of this now to add *another* function for beginners to learn in their first coding lesson. I was trying to squish all the functions I used to use, like xlab, labels, xlim, into the scale_ function for each aesthetic, since that learning generalises.

Diverging Brewer Palettes

These palettes are good for ordinal factors with up to 11 levels where the centre level is a neutral or baseline category and the levels above and below it differ in an important way, such as agree versus disagree options. https://t.co/jgpZ4uTbUf

Sequential Brewer Palettes

These palettes are good for ordinal factors up to 9 levels. https://t.co/tpvEYJs0NX

Qualitative Brewer Palettes

These palettes are good for categorical factors with up to 8 levels (some can handle up to 12). https://t.co/jlizvhEOxK

Discrete Viridis Palettes

Viridis palettes are very good for colourblind-safe and greyscale-safe plots. The work with any number of categories, but are best for larger numbers of categories or continuous colours. https://t.co/eLp3vbTU5i

g <- ggplot() + geom_freqpoly(aes(1:2), binwidth = 1, boundary = 0)
b <- ggplot_build(g)
str(b$data[[1]][4:5])

# xmin: 0 1 2
# xmax: 1 2 3

b2 <- ggplot_build(g + xlim(0, 3))
str(b2$data[[1]][4:5])

# xmin: NA 0 1 2 3
# xmax: 0 1 2 3 NA

@abiyugiday @thomasp85 @IsabellaGhement I think coord_cartesian is more like a zoom. It lets you zoom in and out without changing the underlying plot at all. Limits are more like a filter function for the data in the corresponding aes() column.

@fcstehav @JamesUanhoro @thomas_mock Thanks for the help, @JamesUanhoro and @fcstehav. I've figured out how to articulate the underlying problem. The 2 NA values are in the first computed xmin and last xmax: https://t.co/f1cealnrb5

@bechhof @laura_j_botzet I think I finally figured out how to articulate why this is happening. Thanks for the help @laura_j_botzet and @bechhof :)

https://t.co/f1cealnrb5

@abiyugiday @thomasp85 @IsabellaGhement If your limits aren't exactly *on* boundaries, the first xmin and last xmax will be NA instead of the boundary below (or at) the min limit and above (or at) the max limit. So now I just need to figure out how to explain that concept to students so they can set the right limits.

@abiyugiday @thomasp85 Solved with the help of @IsabellaGhement in the thread starting here:

https://t.co/GsxE0GlY09
@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb Doesn't facet_grid keep your axes the same across all facets unless you turn that off with scales="free"?

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb I think if you're working with data like Likert scales it wouldn't make any sense, but for things like plotting the distribution of p-values, that and boundary = 0 are more sensible defaults.

@abiyugiday I was just writing up an explainer for how to remove the annoying space under the x-axis with expand! It's useful :)

But it isn't going to solve this particular problem. I don't want to change the padding, but match the x-range between separate plots using limits.

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb It will depend on your binwidth and boundary. By default, the bars centre on 0, so if your binwidth is 10, the bins span -5 to 5, and extend by 10s to each side. If you set boundary to 0, the bins span 0 to 10 and extend to each side.

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb Sorry, I was doing that thing of softening my confidence to not seem arrogant. You're 100% right. Setting limits with xlim or limits in a scale_ function definitely removes all of the data outside of the limits *before* geoms are drawn. coord_cartesian just crops the plot.

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb I have the same understanding as you. I just ignore the warning in my own work, but the context is teaching, where it's unsatisfying to tell them to ignore a warning (and bad precedent). They probably don't need the details, but I'd like to understand enough to explain if asked.
@CedScherer Check the rest of my thread for how I do know about that but don't want to teach it in this lesson for a few reasons.

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb I think I get it now. Thanks @IsabellaGhement!

I still think it's a bug, but I can explain that they have to set the limits at the borders between bars. Or set boundary=0 in geom_histogram if relevant. It doesn't fix geom_freqpoly, though.

@IsabellaGhement @bolkerb g <- ggplot() + geom_histogram(
  aes(x = 1:2), binwidth = 1
)

b <- ggplot_build(g)
str(b$data[[1]][4:5])

#> $ xmin: num  0.5 1.5
#> $ xmax: num  1.5 2.5

b2 <- ggplot_build(g + xlim(0, 3))
str(b2$data[[1]][4:5])

#> $ xmin: num  NA 0.5 1.5 2.5
#> $ xmax: num  0.5 1.5 2.5 NA
@JamesUanhoro @fcstehav @thomas_mock Oh, this does work, but in a way I'm not yet sure I can explain to students in a way that won't make them think maybe Excel would be easier!

@bolkerb So what values are getting replaced when all my data are 0-5 and my limits are -5 to 10? The limits aren't removing any data, but you always get this warning for binned geoms. It has something to do with the end-point bins (e.g., if you have 4 groups, there are 8 missing values).

Plus coord_cartesian silently chops off data, and I like having the check of the limits when I really am excluding data from the plot. But it's unsatisfying to tell students that the warning is a false alarm in some circumstances.

I'm writing educational materials, and warnings stress out beginners. I'm emphasising the importance of controlling the range of the axes to compare between similar plots. I know how to use coord_cartesian, but it would be nice to stick to the scale_ functions to start.

Can someone explain why I still get the warning "Removed 2 rows containing missing values" when I limit the x-axis, even when they're *clearly* well outside the range of the data? #rstats

geom_histogram(
  aes(x = rbinom(100, 5, .5)),
  binwidth = 1

In _output.yml (along with your other bs4_book settings):

bookdown::bs4_book:
  css: style.css
  includes:

Please feel free to steal this code or even this exact assignment. The variability means I'm pretty confident that even if students work together, they will have to actually learn the concepts in order to apply another student's code to their own dataset and research question.

It also shows how to give the question columns in the questionnaire table names with a randomised structure. Some of the questions are reverse-coded, indicated by the letter R in the column name, and question names vary in pattern like "q01-R", "R q01", "q01_F", "q01F", etc.

You can use the messy() function to replace a proportion of values of a column with NAs or another missing value. In the demo, I replace some ages with "missing" to make this a character column so students can practice identifying and fixing this.

@Flavio_Azevedo_ I finish with a paragraph summarising my recommendation. Only add explanations about special circumstances, like illness or family leave, if they gave you permission. (For UK acads: US acads tend to be more effusive, so be a little over-the-top if you really are enthusiastic.)

@Flavio_Azevedo_ Then a shorter paragraph on ‚Äúsoft skills‚Äù. Make sure to avoid sexist bias. Explain, with examples if possible, how they work in a team,  handle criticism, meet deadlines, show independence, ask for help, or anything relevant to the position.

@Flavio_Azevedo_ Then give details about those reasons. I usually do one paragraph on their experience/skills with concrete evidence, like their course marks, their papers I‚Äôve read, or skills needed in projects they led.

@Flavio_Azevedo_ I start with how I know the student and for how long, plus some context of my experience. Put your general evaluation in the first paragraph for overwhelmed committees. If you unreservedly and enthusiastically recommend them, say so, and summarise the main reasons.

@Flavio_Azevedo_ It sounds like you know this student well, but eventually you‚Äôll get asked to write recs for students you know less well or from years ago. You can ask the student to give you bullet-points of what experience and qualities you can vouch for that are relevant to the position.

@cconrymurray The "lone genius" PI model of psychology is unsustainable in the face of all the things you need to learn to do good science. #TeamScience is, IMO, the only way forward, but that requires a change in funding models and hiring/promotion.

@cconrymurray This is absolutely not unique to you. There are systematic problems with how most of us were taught stats, how much time we get for continuing professional development, and how we're discouraged from specialising and working in teams in psychology.

@cconrymurray No. There are unfortunately no simple solutions or rules of thumb that you can use here. It really sucks, I know. But power isn't the only way to justify sample size. https://t.co/vKFSwaJ2a7 @lakens

@cconrymurray @lakens @bmwiernik It's OK if the data don't exist yet that would let you estimate that. Now your justification for the sample size should be based on pragmatic constraints, like the number of subjects you can recruit or the amount of funding you have.

@cconrymurray @lakens @bmwiernik I'd say that you have to make a sample-size justification based on something other than a power analysis. It needs to be acknowledged that power analyses of mixed effects designs without realistic parameters from pilot data are just a wild guess.

# the function
hl <- function(code) {
  txt <- rlang::enexpr(code) %>% rlang::as_label()

  downlit::highlight(txt, classes = downlit::classes_pandoc()) %>%
    paste0("<code>", . , "</code>")
}

Code check should specify which aspects it's checking:

- does the code run (for you)?
- does the code run for everyone? (containerised)
- does the code produce the reported results?
- is the internal logic of the code sound?
- does the code follow the scientific logic?

Do a review of your own code to model that the process is normal and critique is meant to be useful.
Suggestion form Daniela Gawehns in the chat: organise a @ReproHack!

My question! Tips and resources to make it easier to review your code:

- knowing about best practices
- make code reusable
- good use of git
- in-person review can be more convenient
- make a README aimed at reviewers
- learn from a community (@turingway)

Students (and others!) are often reluctant to share their code because they're embarrassed. It's up to us to create an atmosphere where everyone feels safe. Give feedback in a way that makes the reviewee open to your suggestions.
-Djura Smits

Marijn van Vliet makes a great point that asking for code and data during review forces the authors to get it into shape for sharing "upon reasonable request", even if you don't formally review the code.

So many great questions in the chat:

"Does research software development needs its own version of the Software Development Cycle?" - Manuel Garcia https://t.co/vkRtWzO7ao

@StephenEglen on "data available on reasonable request". We all know the code and data will eventually disappear if not archived during review. Also acknowledges the constraint of data privacy. I think this is a perfect use for simulated data, to at least check the code logic.

@AkhmerovAnton expresses the common frustration of not being able to access code during review. He always asks, as it's a low-effort way to greatly improve the quality of research. (And sometimes authors catch problems when prepping the code to show him!)

Durja Smits makes the point that code review for industry and academia can have different goals. As academics, is it sufficient to make sure the code runs and produces the same values reported in the paper? Or should code review go deeper into the logic of the code?
If you do code review, is it informal (e.g., colleagues or lab members) or formal (e.g., a code check committee) and do you compensate them (with money or co-authorship)?
If you make research code, do you do code review?

"If you know that your code is going to be reviewed, you have an incentive to do better" -Djura Smits

"Try to make the bar as low as possible for code review ... does this code exist & work?" @StephenEglen

"Code review is one of the important learning mechanisms" @AkhmerovAnton
